title: Can “would” be used twice in an English conditional sentence and still be grammatical? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, if the ‘would’ in the ‘if’ clause has the sense of ‘chose to,’ e.g. “You would get better marks at school if you would stop playing video games all night.” It’s the same sense of ‘would’ as in “I wish you would stop playing video games all night.” We also have the expressions ‘would rather’ and ‘would sooner,’ e.g. “I would be happy to accommodate you, madam, if you would rather have a bigger room.” But most of the time, ‘would’ in the main clause of a conditional sentence is simply wrong.

“It would be nice if you would sit still”. It has a slightly “belt and braces” feel of redundancy to it but I don’t see a fundamental problem. More idiomatic would be: “It would be nice if you sat still” and a super-correct version would be “It would be nice if you were to sit still”.

It’s usually an error, but it’s not utterly impossible, for example: “If you would help us, we would finish much sooner.” Here the first “would” is being used in the sense “kindly agree to” rather than the conditional/counterfactual sense.

When it comes to a sentence with an “if clause”, don’t put a conditional in the “if clause” but a past simple and reserve the conditional for the main clause. I borrow the example from Aoin Douglas : “It would be nice if you sat still”. Never “if you would be nice if you would sit still”.
